title: An absolute masterpiece!
review:
David Lynch, possibly one of the strangest but most adventurous directors in cinema. Fact.

I began watching this film expecting something different from what I got, I was expecting an exceptional film, from all the hype. But what I got was one of the most intense, mysterious, atmospheric, brilliantly plotted, dark and most cinematically masterful and intriguing films I have ever watched.

What starts off with a seriously trippy opening sequence and then an horrific car crash, ends with the viewer almost hypnotised with what has gone by. I wont tell you anything that would spoil the story, but be prepared for surprises.

Every scene in this film has the sort of intensity rarely found elsewhere, it's a truly nightmarish and dreamlike experience, with one of the most creepy scenes I have experienced. It has moments of almost unbearable silence, with the viewer on the edge of their seats as to what will happen next, as in this film...anything can happen.

The story is so complex and almost brain meltingly confusing that many people may be put off by being left in the dark till the end where mostly everything is revealed. But even than it may not be possible to understand what has happened, close attention must be given in a lot of the scenes, especially the scenes with Betty and Rita.

David Lynch should of won the best directer award at the Oscars, as he has created a true masterpiece, with haunting cinematography, subtle but sharp satirical underlines to the narrative and a superb control of the smart and hypnotic lot.

Hell...I've just finished watching it and I'm still hypnotised from what has happened...

title: An absolute mindscrew kinda movie
review: I must say ... This movie is an absolute mindscrew film. I couldn't leave my eyes of the screen for a single minute. It's like you get fired at with super glue. So if you need a dose of mind screwing suspense go watch this film !! Anyways I love it ! The humor is of high quality. The acting is also very good. I won't mention a specific character in the movie but you sure come to really like or dislike them. Especially one that really comes across as being dumb even do the actor is known as being really smart. Again worth every minute of my time ! Don't forget to stack up on drinks and snacks BEFORE turning on the movie!

title: Umm...What?
review:
A bright-eyed young actress travels to Hollywood, only to be ensnared in a dark conspiracy involving a woman who was nearly murdered, and now has amnesia because of a car crash. Eventually, both women are pulled into a psychotic illusion involving a dangerous blue box, a director named Adam Kesher, and the mysterious night club Silencio.

Who? What? When? Where? Why? Well, those are the questions you'll ask when it ends. I'm fairly a confused person right now, knowing nothing that I've been through. I'm a simple-minded person, as you can tell so I don't know if this review will help you or not.

Although very confusing, this film is a confusing, disturbing, and great film. Why great? It just makes you pay attention throughout the film because you don't know what's going on, hence you will be having a good time in this movie.

Yes, and this film is also dark and disturbing. It actually might give me nightmares when I sleep. Oh, well. The acting by Laura Harring and Niomi Watts are very good.

You don't want to watch this film because it might get too confusing, just watch it. I used the net to research and finally get some part of it. However, this is a great piece of work.

title: It totally confuses you, until you accept to understand it
review: According to a wide bunch of people, David Lynch's movies are mostly based on non-sense fantasies and dreamworld trips more than on really intriguing, deep and smart plots. Approaching this movie, I was trying to understand whether what "people" think is true or if it only reflects a lazy approach to cinema, where everything is not clear should be revealed brightly at the end of the plot, with a wonderful and heartbreaking twist. This is not the case. The story is so linear and simple, but it appears this way only if you are able to reconstruct and give a sense to every single scene. Anyway, this is not the classical movie where a story is broken into pieces which are then mixed ad-hoc, allowing you to understand everything only at the last scenes. Here there is more: you have to think, to watch with your eyes, with your brain and, of course, to restart the movie from the beginning more than once. Then, even if everything appears to be clear, you must use some of the remaining scenes you didn't consider before to complete the engaging puzzle you are trying to solve, and finally reach a state of satisfaction and of admiration for a great movie and a great director.

title: An in depth look at a tortured soul
review: David Lynch is an artist. Pure and simple. His most recent film MD is a beautiful look at such topics as jealousy, fear, love, hate and betrayal. The concept of a film as a perpetual mystery where the viewer is asked to explore the hidden meanings as opposed to "who did it" is a wonder to behold. I have read interpretation of the film ranging from a veiled blasphemy to a modern day rendition of the Wizard of Oz. I believe that Lynch requires an open mind and a superior intellect from his viewers if they hope to tap the arcane wisdom that his movies hold. Is Mulholland Dr. something that will appeal to everyone? No, and that is just fine. As long as Lynch enjoys what he is doing and has the respect of his peers and fans, everyone else can go pack the local multiplex to see the drool du joure.

title: This is possibly the greatest film ever made.
review:
David Lynch understands filmaking. The fact that he remains an outsider filmmaker, after a career as studded with great films as Stanley Kubrick's, is a standing accusation of Hollywood, as I'm sure Kubrick's career was. Right now his latest film is out, yet my hometown isn't showing it. I can't believe that. The latest schlock from whoever is there, but not David Lynch's latest.

I keep hearing that Mulholland Drive is hard to understand. I don't get it. I think that, like almost all his films, it's much clearer than the kind of stitched together narratives that seem typical even of many good films. A gal comes to Hollywood, full of dreams - the old cliché. She doesn't do so well, but she does find love, she thinks. She ends up betrayed, on a lot of different levels, perhaps most importantly, by her own hopes, and she kills herself in despair.

I think it's a pretty simple film.

But Mulholland Drive is deep too. It's about the darkness, inside us and outside us, that can drive our lives towards nothingness, but also about the resilience that clings to hope, reaches out for redemption, even when all hope is lost.

Naomi Watts. My God, in view of what she has done since Mulholland Drive, how did she pull off such a magnificent, detailed, emotional, transcendent performance? How did she do it? Well, I guess Lynch played a role in that. But wow.

Mulholland drive is a modern day Wizard of Oz. It lives in a Valhalla of film perfection that few films ever achieve. Watt's character, like Dorothy, seeks the Emerald City and finds that her quest leads to sham and betrayal. But she also finds that what she seeks, she always had, and what she has, no one can take away.

title: Confusing for most but the most rabid Lynch lovers
review:
Mulholland Drive will appeal to aficionados of David Lynch, but for those who merely like his movies - or, worse, haven't seen any of them (Elephant Man, Eraserhead, Dune, Lost Highway), it'll be a thoroughly incomprehensible mess. I suspect it's not, really, but figuring it out calls for mental powers the like of which I'll never have. The movie does more than merely blur the line between reality and fantasy, it obliterates it.

For about two thirds of the film, everything sort of makes some kind of sense. It's weird enough, sure, but it seems to follow some logic. Then Something happens, and the movie goes off the rails. Intentionally, I'm sure - it's the kind of movie for which clues are very, very subtle, and it's entirely up to the viewer to piece them together. Even so, different viewers will come up with different explanations for the events in Mulholland Drive.

The basic gist is this: Betty Elms (Naomi Watts), fresh off the plane from Canada, arrives in Hollywood to make her fortune as an actress, along with approximately 40,000 other ingenues each year (taken from the Great Book of Stats I've Made Up). She has it a little easier than most novices, though, in that she gets to stay in the nice apartment of her aunt, an actress who's conveniently out of town and has permitted Betty to stay. Ah, but Betty quickly discovers that she's not alone - there's a naked woman in her shower, and it turns out she's an amnesiac. The woman takes the name of Rita from a nearby movie poster, and Betty decides to help her find out who she is while keeping nosy neighbors out of the loop.

Now, the viewer knows that Rita was in a car accident on the titular road in the opening scene of the movie. She was being driven in a limo, and the driver pulled the car over and pulled a gun on her. Before he can shoot, though, two drag racing cars careen around the turn, and one smashes into Rita's car, killing everyone except her. She subsequently wanders into Los Angeles itself and hides out at Betty's aunt's place.

As with most Lynch movies, though, nothing is what it seems. All Rita has in her purse is a mysterious, oddly shaped blue key - and stacks of money. When she and Betty visit a diner, Rita thinks she recognizes the waitress's first name - Diane - and maybe even flashes on a full name, Diane Selwyn. Could Rita be Diane? The ladies figure out Selwyn's phone number and call it, but they get a recording. Then they visit it, but when they find the woman's apartment, they find Selwyn had switched with someone - and at THAT apartment, they find a dead body.

But that's not where it gets weird. In the middle of the night, Rita wakes up with the word Silencio on her lips, and she brings Betty to a strange club with the same name. In what's been described as the most moving sequence in the film, the women watch an interesting performance - first an emcee tells them that "There is no band" and that all is just a tape, and then a singer belts out a Spanish version of Rob Orbison's "Crying," which apparently has quite an effect on Rita (who cries) and Betty (who shakes). After the performance, Rita discovers she has a small blue box, and back at the apartment she opens it. And that's about when the movie goes completely nutso.

What does it all mean? I do not know. Who are all of these people? I do not know. I don't know much about this movie, and I just saw the thing. I fear it's entirely beyond my comprehension, but I did find a good analysis of it online.

I like mysteries. I like having to figure things out, but I don't particular enjoy movies that have a zillion possibilities, depending on how the viewer wishes to interpret things. Or, if that's how the movie's going to be, I kind of wish the clues made some sort of sense. Otherwise, it's just a cacophony of white noise - nothing makes sense, so nothing is there.

title: Lynch's biggest achievement
review: This movie is too good for words. Captivating through its great camera work, intriguing in an almost demanding matter, brilliant performances by the whole cast, music that is enchantingly fitting and as usually things that don't make much sense but are thought-provoking and moving on a gut level. This is my favorite David Lynch film, and the film that first got me into his work which I encourage everyone to watch. For this film especially you might want to devote 3 or 4 viewings if you are eager to shed light to its mysterious and confusing plot-but trust me, it's worth it. All in all, one of the most powerful cinematic experiences you'll have for a long time.

title: A Film That Blows Your Mind
review:
Here is a film that will leave you wondering of what has really happened in it, and yet keep you highly amazed and excited. David Lynch has achieved this difficult combination with his masterpiece "Mulholland Drive".

The story in the beginning is quite straightforward: A girl (Harring) narrowly escapes her murder thanks to a car accident that kills her would-be killers. However, the accident brings amnesia to her, so she wanders aimlessly around, until she finds refuge to a house. In this house, Betty, an aspiring young actress (Watts) takes her under her protection and tries to help her find out what has happened. From some point onward, however, nothing is straightforward anymore: Who is really the girl? Who is really Betty? How are the two of them connected? The movie is open to several interpretations, but after reading some excellent IMDb message board postings, it was easy for me to come up with a solid conclusion of what has really happened. Of course, I am not going to reveal it here, as I will spoil the magic of this excellent film! What I can say however, is that David Lynch has produced a film that is full of symbolism, hidden clues, and art. Although it is basically a "crime" film, in practice it is far beyond that. Dream and reality are intertwined, and in the end everything is turned upside down.

The performances of the two lead actresses could not be better suited for this film: They are both excellent and fit perfectly in their roles. Of course, acting is good across the board, as well.

Lynch's definitely best movie: 10/10.

title: A puzzle well worth exploring
review:
"Mulholland Drive" is one of the most critically acclaimed movies of this decade, as well as one of the most talked-about. Its dreamlike ambiguity and refusal to explain itself (director David Lynch will only discuss the movie in the most cryptic terms) guarantees that viewers will always debate it. Not bad for something that started out as a failed TV pilot.

At first, "Mulholland Drive" has standard mystery elements to it, such as the gorgeous amnesiac brunette (Laura Elena Harring) who calls herself "Rita" after Rita Hayworth, and the sparkly blonde aspiring actress, Betty (Naomi Watts) who thinks it would be fun to make like Nancy Drew and help Rita discover her true identity. You can easily see how this set-up could have become a TV show, which only makes the movie's twists more astonishing. But even in the earlier, sunnier parts of the movie, things lurk in the shadowsbehind dumpsters, in corporate offices or cheap apartmentsand eventually these physical and psychological demons take control. Characters switch identities, people and objects return in surprising ways, and the already complicated puzzle becomes about ten times stranger.

I won't say too much more about "Mulholland Drive"'s mysteries, because you can easily find theories, explanations, and debates online. (What did people ever do when they watched these kinds of ambiguous movies before the Internet?) Perhaps the biggest clue is one of the movie's themes: this is Los Angeles, a city where fantasy seems more real than reality does.

Watts made her name with her accomplished performance here. She goes from over-the-top wholesomeness to romantic passion to self-loathing despair, and succeeds at the tricky task of being an actress playing an actress in Betty's stunning audition scene. But I'm surprised that Harring hasn't found comparable success: not only is she beautiful, she makes for a touchingly vulnerable Rita.

The baffling nature of "Mulholland Drive" is not alone what makes it a great movie. Rather, the best part of the movie is that it is captivating and entertaining enough to make you want to decipher it. Sequences such as the "Club Silencio" centerpiece are so vivid and haunting that it's a pleasure to try to figure out how they fit into the overall scheme.

title: Mindblowing in every way
review:
before i start i have to say one thing. You HAVE to watch this movie twice. The first time i saw it i understood absolutely nothing of what was going on. I was blown away and i kinda HAD TO watch the movie again. Because i needed to understand it. But as i said i understood almost nothing of the film the first time. The second time though, i discovered a lot of clues and saw different things that could help me unsolve the riddle. It is impossible'to solve the mystery completely. And every viewer will come up with their own conclusions. And that is what makes this movie so great. The characters are great, the actors are great (the acting starts a little dull, but it is all done for a reason)the camera angles everything. I have seen this movie about 4 times or something like that and it is definitely the best riddlesolving movie and it is actually as good as other classics like memento, the usual suspects and donnie darko.

p.s i have to say, this movie IS NOT for everybody. If you are the kind of person who love going to the cinema to watch the new American pie movie, don't watch this film. But if you like a good mystery this movie is amazing

title: That Silencio Scene, Oh!
review: The Silencio scene is a microcosm for the more general force of the movie, its dream-like quality, dream in the double sense, the one sense being as opposed to wakefulness and the other sense being as a deep wish, fantasy, or longing------------that beautiful song being artificial, and then just the virtuosic job of presenting the dream-like quality, the fact that certain actors were cast to look like Naomi Watts, and how iconic some of the characters and places are, as far as characters go I will refer you especially to Mimi I think her name is, the women that manages the apartment complex Naomi is living in. And then the end, that last shot with the faces of the two women staggered and the music and Naomi smiling, glowing, that incandescent smile.

title: A Film Poem
review:
Never seen in my life, a film like this before.. Absolutely perfect. Of a kind that opens your mind. Of a kind that apart from entertaining, offers lots of hint to think, and think in a way that you haven't done before. Did you have? It is a totally different, innovative, amazing, unbelievable film. David Lynch is a genius. If you haven't still seen the movie, you have to see it to understand what I exactly mean. "It's all an illusion!!" "Do you believe a man's behavior determines his life?" And what about your life? Which certain behavior and choices have determined or will determine your life? "We don't stop here!" Where you in the wrong place the wrong time? "My name is RITA?" Would you prefer sometimes to forget who you were, what you had done and become someone else? Would you prefer, sometimes, to be someone else? Someone like Rita Hayworth? Have you regretted for your choices?? Oh, yes! It's all an illusion. That's not the reality. This is not, what you thought it was!! This is completely something totally else!! "We wish you all the luck of the world with you!" And where did the luck gone?? It went to Rita who probably stole your dreams...and left a small second part/role for you! You choose which reality you will live? Which you like most? What about behavior? What about conformism? What about " I sense trouble?" What about a strange key? Will you keep it? What about the fear in front of an illusion, in front of a big lie? What about meanings?

That's how I sensed this unique film.. I highly recommend it as a masterpiece of a kind! Gina K.

title: wow BOB wow
review:
What a great film. As was mentioned by others- it gets in your head and stays there. I watched the DVD 3 times in one night about 6 days ago (1st at normal speed, then fast forward, then normal speed again). Then I read everything I could find on the internet about it. I didn't have a clue before I saw it what to expect. I only knew that I generally liked David Lynch films. But man oh Manischevitz I'm still thinking constantly about this film... To get the full experience you should really know nothing about the story going in.

Naomi Watts... I didn't even know who the heck she was. I thought she was the dark haired chick all through the movie. But what a performance she gave. Spectacular. And the other lead actress wasn't too shabby either.

This is in my top ten all time list. FYI, other films in that list would probably include (not a complete list) "Dr. Strangelove", "Two Lane Blacktop", "The Wild Bunch", "The Bride of Frankenstein", "Carnival of Souls", and "2001".

Reading the other IMDb comments it's obvious that many people don't agree with the take that this is great, or even good. Well, to each his own. But if you like a flick to make you think and feel vs. hear a bunch of explosions and fart jokes this film is for you.

title: My o My...
review: Can this be any better than already is? NO. i know there will be people saying yes maybe, but it's already done for and its hands down amazingly beautiful in every way. Questions from start to end....it cracks my brain open and loving it. This being the second film watching from Lynch has made me a fan right when the credits showed. I now'E seen other's and they're all gratefully made. But i just cant seem to purely Love the other films like this one. Don't want to ruin scenes and tell much at all. Top of all movies in my favorite list to be at the number 1 spot. Don't know why but I now consider calling Naomi Watts Mulholland Dr.

title: Once again operation mindfuck
review:
Don't believe the hype! Or do believe?

This kind of films drives everyone crazy, and is for those with good will who believe in the good a topic for discussions for some days at least, for others it's a pure waste of time.

I am writing this comment to get rid of the aftermath, I have watched this film half an hour ago, and my intention is to get an ANSWER! That is what probably everyone wants after watching this movie. Besides no one mentioned the term "mindfuck" what amazed me.

It is absolutely to be categorized in the mindfuck genre, for those who are not familiar with this term have a look at wikipedia, or read the Illuminatus trilogy. In these books the meaning of mindfuck is just overloading the brain with that much nonsense with literally "no sense", so that the brain after endless loops trying to solve the riddle just "resets", and all brain washings you had had in your life are just erased and you are able to see the world as it really is. Just as far as I remember it.

There is a hype about such kind of movies, they tend to get cult, although no one is able to describe the meaning, there are just some guessings. I am not that person who follows the hype, although I am quite impressed. And I do like solving riddles.

OK, let us start systematically - what possibilities are there?

A) It has got a meaning, but is just very (very very) hard to find.

B)It is mindfuck.

C) It is "art", i.e. compare it with a painting, there are always several interpretations, they just have an (subtle) effect. In other words: It works on the subconsciousness. Or - in other other words - it is dream-like.

C: I cannot imagine this solution, therefor it is too much complicated and "mindfucking". And in my opinion, movies with a story line cannot just be art and just have effect. A story line implies something that can be understood by the mind.

B: From the first impression: that's it. It has got no meaning. But why then this love for details, this sense for art and this truly complicated plot. What is the intention of Lynch? Is it just to confuse in a very artful way? Then it would be just manipulation of the viewer, to create a superhuman aura, why is someone creating and telling a riddle what cannot be solved? If this would be true I would be really enraged.

A: Would be nice, but all the attempts of explanation I have read so far seem to be very far-fetched.

Everyone thinks that just because no one is able to understand the plot Lynch has to be a genius, somehow superhuman. And the movie has to be great. Is it this way? I do not think so. I think staying on the ground is the best thing to do.

But nevertheless I will try to solve this riddle, trying to get on the bottom of the plot. Perhaps Lynch has just a very complicated way of expressing things :).

PS: As far as the vote is concerned: No extremes for this movie.

title: Lynch is not perfect
review:
After viewing this film, i was not only completely and utterly confused by it but also was left with a bitter taste. Other reviews say that this movie is "perfect," and "Lynch at his best." However I felt that for the majority of the film, all the dialogue seemed forced, unrealistic and about as smooth as a piece of sandpaper. This was the first film by Lynch that I had ever seen, and I am now turned off after hearing his writing style. The visuals are, I will admit, very dramatic and effective to the scene. The only problem was that I had no idea what was happening in the scene.

By far the best part of the movie was the lesbian sex scene. What else is there to say.

title: Mulholland Drive is a film with a key
review: . That means you need to find the key to open it (its meanings), to read it. At the very beginning we see dancing couple multiplied over one another using so called "blue key", special effect used by TV to place a figure (shot in studio) inside an environment, usually exterior (street, nature etc.). If we take this as a key then we realize that two female characters (Rita and Betty) are actually one and the same woman (a box appears later in the film again with a blue key). Rita/Betty is dying after a car accident and in her last moments she sees her life  her coming to Hollywood as a young aspiring actress and her ending as a hooker. Death keeps appearing in different occasions and shapes. The Silenzio club is a place where Rita/Betty meet death on a stage. The singer is introduced by the announcer saying that the performance will be a"play-back". That means not being "live". That's why Rita/Betty cries. At the end of the movie there is also a very impressive appearance of deathetc. Mulholland Drive is a way to the other world, the world of death (in short).

title: Tom Casey Reviews Mulholland Drive
review: David Lynch is difficult because he makes demands on his audience. He takes meticulous care to fabricate an atmosphere that is, culturally speaking, a collation. The clothes, music, and behavioral idiom is out of pace, yet we see ourselves. Stranger than anything we could have imagined, his world is finally recognizable as our own. If genius is the ability to make connections, David Lynch is a genius of film who connects inner experience to the objects and individuals from without that mold and influence it. MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a film preoccupied with identity. On its surface, it is the story of a young woman who won a dance contest and a chance to have a Hollywood audition. Though by no means clear until much later in the film, she has mediocre talent and falls prey to destructive seductions that turn her dream into a nightmare and destroy her. But what Lynch has done with this Hollywood cliché is magical. It's all in the telling: his trick is to hide his story by cryptically putting it right in front of you. Time after time, the viewer's conventional expectations lead to wrong conclusions, raising the level of confusion and suspense. Like BLUE VELVET, MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a mystery, told from an emotional rather than a rational language of meaning. This is important to realize; it's why Lynch is unintelligible to so many. Without Freudian understanding, the depth of his insight and the richness of his art cannot be comprehended consciously. The meticulous clues that he puts before yousometimes literally in your facewill be misread or overlooked. BLUE VELVET, an Oedipal allegory, takes a tour through the mindscapes of sex and guilt in a young man processing the shock of his father's heart attack. MULHOLLAND DRIVE similarly works from the inside out, but its canvass is much larger, challenging the validity of American optimism. By using the metaphor of dreams, he explores the conflict between the ideal of Hollywood as a dream machine, and the corrosive realities of life. Dreams can be beautiful and turn terrifying. Dreams always express a wish, often reversing facts of the waking world. More importantly, as Freud insisted, the dream is the dreamer. Hollywood creates the dreams of our culture, projecting the sex and violence of our collective Id. Id is very much the springboard for David Lynch. For most of the entire film, MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a dream being dreamt by a young aspiring actress named Betty. This is not explicit, though in typical fashion Lynch has put it subtly in front of us: in the opening scene the camera plays on a pillow and we hear the sound of a person sleeping out of range. In a subsequent scene Betty says, "This is the place of dreams." Then the camera follows a limousine traveling at night on Mulholland Drive. It soon becomes a hearse of sorts, and that subliminal impression, once planted, remains. Throughout the film/Betty's dream, the characters and their actions must often be inverted to understand their interplay as continuous to the fabric of the story. By this calculus it is Betty, not Rita, who is searching for her identity, and the story of Betty's triumphant audition is her wish that she had not, in reality, failed. When Adam, the director, meets her eyes and seems to fall in love with her, we should suspect the truth is his indifference. When Rita begins to sense that she is responsible for a murder, Freud's delineation of dreamwork points to Betty. In dreams, manifest content masks latent meaning; there are layers and layers. Dreams are constructed from images of waking life: we later discover the sources of Betty's dream material: the dark angular man in the diner, the waitress's name tag, a blue key, are reproduced in Betty's dream with a significance they did not have when she casually encountered them. But we don't know that to begin with. We do know that walls, doors, windows, boxes, and bed are the symbols of Betty's entrapment, culminating in a vision of Silencio, the place of truth and "crying" where Death is the keeper of dreams. Cartoon gangsters shorn of their menace through slapstick, should be viewed with foreboding, for everything is its opposite. Here too, the Cowboy's mythic strength is denatured, stripped of his status as icon; he is not a benign protector, rather he seems more a genderless demon who awakens Betty/Diane to what we shortly learn is Diane's horrible reality. The lesbian affair between Betty and Rita is in fact a destructive union riven with ungovernable passions. In one of the last scenes Diane masturbates furiously, missing her orgasm repeatedly as a final frustration before the barrier to guilt gives way and parental homunculi creep under the doorway, exploding into the room as an Id-fueled horror of accusation. Proust wrote that there is no access to something original because, by virtue of its originality, it defies analysis, it can only stand apart with a life of its own as a reference to subsequent works that may evolve under its influence. "In short, this art which is so complicated is in fact the only living art. It alone expresses for others and renders visible to ourselves that life of ours that cannot effectually observe itself and of which the observable manifestations need to be translated and, often, to be read backwards and laboriously deciphered." David Lynch is such an artist, and MULHOLLAND DRIVE is such a film. Any attempt to force his meaning will fail; he will not be understood too quickly, and perhaps never in the same way by different viewers. To paraphrase T.S. Eliot on Shakespeare, all we can hope for in time is to be wrong about him in a new way.

title: Brilliant
review: In Mulholland Drive, David Lynch produced his best movie to date and one of my favorite movies ever. I like it so much because it's one of those rare cases where every expectation I have when I sit in front of the silver screen is fulfilled. It has a clever plot, which makes you actually think and not switch off your brain, it has fantastic performances, especially from the two female leads, it has great, great music (Llorando a capella is divine!), beautiful photography and expert directing. And most of all, it takes you away from your seat to a 2-hour fantasy trip. Explanations of what is actually going on you can easily find everywhere. However, I'm sure Lynch wants YOU to build the story and not simply digest something that someone else has chewed for you.

title: good film for Lynch fans
review: This is one of my favorite David Lynch films, I liked that the room for interpretation for the viewer is wide open. As the story unfolds there is a great deal for one to ponder and try to figure out. Naomi Watts and Laura Herring give excellent performances. In true Lynch fashion, he delivers the unusual and the twists and turns are plenty. This is a movie that can be watched more than once and still be interesting. Angelo Badalamente composed beautiful scores that were haunting and helped to set the film's eerie tone. If you are not a Lynch fan or are the type that likes to be spoon fed plots, this is not the film for you. David Lynch was nominated for best director in 2002 and should have one the honor for doing such an amazing job, but the Oscar went to Ron Howard for A Beautiful Mind.

title: Great Movie
review: Mulholland Drive is one of Lynch's best films by far. It is filled with everything you can ask for: action, horror, suspense, lesbian love scenes....Lynch is able to the viewer into this strange and bizarre world where we are never sure what is real and what is not. First time Lynch viewers should not expect something that makes complete sense, otherwise expect a major headache at the end. This movie forces the viewers to observe and develop their own conclusions about the story. Whether you love it or hate it, Mulholland Drive is an unforgettable, haunting movie. After seeing it for the first time, I could not get it out of my mind for the next week. When a movie has that much of a hold on you, you know it has effected you in some way. This movie is guaranteed to thrill you in some way, whether it be Lynch's unique storytelling, the great visuals, or mesmerizing soundtrack. This is a definite must for all Lynch fans as well as anyone else who is into surreal films. Those unfamiliar with Lynch's work might have a difficult time with this movie, but sometimes the best thing to do with this movie is just to roll with it. And make you watch it more than once, it's gets better the second time around since you can pick up on the the subtleties you missed the first time. Go see this movie!

title: probably the only directly solvable Lynch Film
review: Mulholland Dr. is a perfect film in all aspects. the directing is definitely Lynch's Abstract misdirection. All the elements of the usual Lynch Film are there... Unnamed horror (man behind Winkies), A beginning of "not human" or "not real" characters, symbolic spoilers, uncovering a secret that only gets darker, and the confusion of all until the very end (SPOILER... which is the only part of reality, It's all a dream until Diane wakes up after the dream flickers away with the second look of the cowboy, you can tell it's a dream just by looking at the beginning before the title even comes up... the jitterbug surrealism, contest winner(Diane), and then you come to a fuzzy shot of the bed and pillow of diane's room, you know because of the lamp and bed/pillow covers . all of the beginning is connected to parts of said figure out why we've been shown this and from who's perspective, you realize that this is the only way lynch could have shown it... a dream of a dreamer and i love the line "now it's like i'm in this dream place" -Betty(abstract wanton vision of Diane) I'd say Lynch's theory's from as far back as Eraserhead all the way to Lost Highway came together for this one. probably the only directly solvable lynch film (excluding the purely symbolic Blue Velvet and Eraserhead) this mystery you just keep watching and learning new things. great original story and direction with cool guest stars. powerful emotional consideration with Mr.Lynch, every scene a reason, every feeling a connection, and every character shown masked first. don't forget... the curtains always go up until after it's over. well worth watching if you want something intelligent and original.

title: Hollywood: The 8th Deadly Sin
review: This amazing film manages to pay homage to many film classics (ie. "Touch of Evil," "Sunset Boulevard," "Vertigo," "Barton Fink," "The Player," "Perfect Blue") and still be a jaw-dropping piece of cinematic originality. "Mulholland Dr.," also inspired by pulp fiction (the genre, not the movie), turns the missing girl/ mistaken identity format around-about, in-and-out. Lynch's greatest strength has been his audacious style, a dazzling combination of Franz Kafka and Frank Capra, Dario Argento and "Happy Days." This film presents Hollywood as an obscene nightmare covered in a pink patina of promise. Lynch's trademark sub- bass groans loom beneath '50's bubblegum pop hits. Pretty girls in bouffants coo lipstick lullabies while doped-up divas hallucinate and harangue hipster gangsters. In Lynch's La La Land, names are incidental, faces are interchangeable, nothing is real. Only one character, Adam Kesher, even attempts to return to reality with his (ultimately) false promise: "I'm Going Home."

title: Excellence in every aspect (Possible Spoilers)
review:
Upon viewing this for the fourth time, I decided i would post a review highlighting the elements that I enjoyed the most. Firstly, I must warn that this film is not for those who are looking for a simple "turn your brain off" movies. Also, to truly appreciate this film it takes numerous viewings. **Possible Spoilers Herein**

Every performance in this film is amazing. Although Naomi Watts has excellent scenes in which she cries and explodes, the true talent is in the subtly of her acting. When she opens the purse for the first time with Camilla, you can see the expression on Betty's face showing that she knows its actually hers, but still acts out her role as Betty (enjoying seeing Rita's guilt). The first time I saw this I thought the acting was ridiculous, but now I see this was David Lynch's way to show the fakeness in Betty's dream. Also, I found Laura Harring's performance excellent in its subtly.

The sound quality is amazing. Everything is crystal clear. Example, when Camilla in running down the street we can hear her shoes clicking against the road. The score was excellent, and helped further the mood. I also noticed quiet, almost inaudible noises throughout the movie.

The lighting in this film is excellent. If we look at the difference between Betty and Diane, we can see that Betty is bathed in a aura of light, whereas Diane has dark shadows cast upon her.

Overall, this is the most thorough movie I have ever seen, and for this reason it is my favorite. Highly recommended for those who enjoy an intelligent film.

title: In The Eye of the Beholder
review:
I came to MULHOLLAND DRIVE with extreme reluctance. Although I've seen most of Lynch's work, it has been more by accident than by design, and I had no expectation of great interest in the film. For Lynch is an extremely divisive director: you either like his work or you do not, and by and large I fall into the latter category. So I sympathize with those who loathe everything about the film--but at the same time I am surprised by how much I myself admired it.

Opening with an attempted murder thwarted by an unexpected car-crash, the film presents us with a beautiful woman (Laura Harring) who stumbles into Los Angeles in shock and suffering from amnesia. Using the name "Rita," she crosses paths with pert and pretty Betty Elms (Naomi Watts), new to the city and in search of a film career. Betty quickly decides to shelter Rita, and the two women begin to search for Rita's true identity.

A number of subplots, seemingly random incidents, and bizarre events complicate the basic premise; even so, I think most viewers will be able to buy into the film and find themselves extremely curious about the film's approaching conclusion. But therein lies the rub, for it is exactly at this point that the film suddenly deconstructs and forces you to completely reevaluate everything you've previously seen.

A number of recent films, including the extremely popular SIXTH SENSE and THE OTHERS, have used a similar device, a sudden twist that spins your basic perception of the overall story. In both cases, however, these were logical extensions of the basic plot; the device in MULHOLLAND DRIVE, however, is not, and it does not so much spin perception as it completely overturns and then completely reinterprets the entire film up to that point. And there are only two possible reactions: jaw-dropping astonishment or a savage disgust with the whole thing.

There have been endless interpretations and analyses of this film, and many people complain that they don't understand it. I may be running against the tide here, but I have to say that you shouldn't try to "understand" MULHOLLAND DRIVE; instead, accept it as a journey into an extremely disturbed mind as it plays games with itself. For with this film, Lynch essentially takes us inside madness itself, an insanity that dreams Hollywood dreams grown into monsters of the subconscious.

Yes, I do think there is much to admire here in spite of several very obvious flaws--not the least of which is a distinct difference in tone as the film shifts between portions originally planned for television and portions filmed when Lynch realized he could salvage the project as a feature film. But at the same time, admiring is not necessarily liking: MULHOLLAND DRIVE is a very dark place, and for myself one visit was enough.

Gary F. Taylor, aka GFT, Amazon Reviewer

title: Mulholland Dr was a great movie.
review:
The film Mulholand Dr. is a movie that stands out. It is a film that you can not truly relate to any other film, it is completely original. After you are done viewing it, you and everybody else will be totally silent, bewildered. There are so many connections in this movie that all hit you at the end of the film, making you want to sit back down to understand it all. The main reason I love this film, is that you can't truly understand this film in one sitting and it will leave you with many questions to debate over. Every time I watch it, I learn something new. I enjoying watching this film with friends, arguing over the meaning of the film. This film brings all genres to the table, and also adds a real artistic feel. Although the movie hits you hard and is very unsettling, I recommend it to all viewers allowed to watch R films and die hard Lynch fans.

Cptmullet2003

title: One of the greatest cinematic achievements... ever?
review: Yes, in my strong opinion, Mulholland Dr. is one of the greatest movies of its kind. In many ways, Mullholland Dr. is more a work of art than a movie intended to entertain and amuse. After seeing a Mullholland Dr., you'll feel many different things depending on what kind of person you are. My feelings were a mix of awe and sadness (as corny as it may sound), and most of all confusion. Many will be turned off and ultimately hate it for its complexity, which is unfortunate. The cinematography is breathtaking (the film takes on a very soft, colorful and dreamy look). Almost every scene is memorable: from the opening jitterbug sequence, to those downright disturbing smiles on the old people's faces, to the man behind Winkies, the cowboy, Club Silencio, and the ending... just to name a few out of the whole movie. After seeing the movie more than 5 times, I still find myself amazed all throughout the film, picking up a little more of something new each viewing. This is also one of the darkest movies I have ever seen next to Lynch's other classic Eraserhead. Not accessible and by no means mainstream, if you can bring yourself to appreciate it, you will be more than rewarded. Being someone who watches many movies, I have still yet to come across another film that has as much impact as this one... and I doubt if I ever will.

title: ... kinda
review: OK, the movie is about guilt. The blue key given by the hit-man symbolizes this. In the part where the guy explains his worst fear, that actually is her (the main character) worst fear, coming face to face with her own guilt. And thats when happiness and innocence of what she used to be comes back and haunts her. The blue key + the blue box which her former lover is sucked into= the events which lead up to her suicide. But the only problem is that i still have holes in the story, like what is the "cowboy" and what does the part where she finds her own dead body have to do with anything, and why is David lynch so damn confusing. meh, i tried, and I'm going to keep on trying too.

title: So it was all a Dr.
review: David Lynch once again shows his immense but ultimately annoying talent for starting any number of fascinating hares and then failing to round any of them them up again. In this tale of an encounter between an ingénue and an amnesiac femme fatale (but which is which?)he clatters along merrily for an hour and a half and is then forced to take a surreal left turn to wind everything up quickly, like a schoolboy caught short writing an exam essay. Is Lynch just another "art" director who thinks he can easily wing it in the low-brow genre of the thriller, only to fall flat on his face? Maybe. But there are some great scenes here too--if Lynch would only learn to discipline himself, to lay down some ground rules and stick with them, he could make films to rival and maybe outclass Tarantino.

title: Loose ends vs. hypnotic images (as usual)
review:
And who's winning the big prize? It's hard to tell. Every Lynch film has to be evaluated this way, I think. On one hand, you've got the surreal and beautiful happenings, and on the other, all the nonsense. You put it in the scales, and usually the first outweighs the second. By far.

This is the first time I found myself doubting about it, because the mind toying was just way too much. The last minutes felt like a rehash of 'Lost Highway', but even more hallucinatory and illogic, and condensed in much less time. The fact that the crazy part started just when the story was getting REALLY interesting was a pain too. They were all noticeable symptoms of what everybody knows: Mulholland Drive was meant to be a TV series, in the same vein of "Twin Peaks". So the first half of this movie is, basically, a pilot (introduction of characters, some action, a bit of thriller, humor...) with a zillion of loose ends, and the rest, a milk shake of undeveloped ideas. Creepy and fascinating, but too much incoherent even for Lynch.

The main reason this movie is, despite of all, a winner, is that Lynch has outdone himself this time. First, there are four or five shots in this movie which I can describe simply as unforgettable. Second, we are introduced to hilarious characters (the cowboy, for example) who are worth the movie alone. Third, we are presented with a few sequences in which Lynch shows a great sense of humor. And fourth, Badalamenti is still at top form.

So, yes, he has done it again. But the margin is getting narrow. I'm really looking forward his next movie, because I have no idea which path will Lynch take. I'm already waiting.

RATING: 7.4

title: Outstanding!
review: Mulholland Dr. is one of my favorite movies of all time. So far, at least in my opinion, it is clearly the best American drama of the 21st century. It may very well be the best drama of the 21st century, challenged only by such masterpieces as "City Of God" and "Ying Xiong" (a.k.a. "Hero"). I strongly believe that it should have won an Oscar for Best Picture, Best Actress, Best Director and should have been nominated for Best Supporting Actress, Best Cinematography and Best Sound. The movie is beautifully filmed and looks mesmerizing, so I sort of understand the people who love it despite not understanding the plot even after repeated viewings (although I still have to learn how to stop rolling my eyes).

title: Dark and intricate
review:
I have seen Mulholland Drive twice and plan to see it several more times, without hope of really understanding it. The range of sorrow, fear, foreshadowing, ingenue virginity, sensuality and despair exceed those of Blue Velvet, the other Lynch film I know well.

Oddly, what appeals to me most is the incomprehensibility of the plot, Diane's utter transformation in the middle. (Normally this type of veering development (really non-development) annoys me.) A dream with flashbacks, touching something of the lover, sadist and assassin in each of us.

I expect I will learn something new about myself and humanity every time I see it.

title: This movie is awful
review:
I just spent the last 2 hours and 25 minutes watching this awful movie and found it to contain nothing but gratuitous bullshit.

The rest of the comments tout this as some sort of "thriller" that "makes you think" -- and the authors of these comments would no doubt condemn me as "someone who just likes to passively watch a story and not use my head."

They are entitled to their opinion - but I know "intelligence" and "creativity" when I see it, and David Lynch possesses neither. Lynch is clearly either completely insane, or deliberately gimmicky.

Don't see this film unless you don't mind wasting over 2 hours of your time, or are a pseudo-intellectual moron.

title: Triple threads - spoilers in last section
review:
Hollywood has traditionally been very good at making films about itself and Mulholland Drive nudges ahead of even the other street name title, Sunset Boulevard (1950). Both films are effective because, in contrast to usual Hollywood fare, cynicism is given an unremitting free reign.

Mulholland is about the use and abuse of both sex and money in power and personal politics. It is ironic that Naomi Watts is given an actress's script to kill for and she makes the very best of it. Could Julia have done it? No. What about Gwyneth? Possibly. And Cate? OK, well yes, but even she would have had to be at her peak to match Watt's range which is breathtaking. She so effectively counterpoints the naivety of the Hollywood dream with the reality.

Non-spoiler guide

One way of making sense of this film is to consider it as having three interwoven perspectives; the reality storyline (in so far as the cinema can ever represent reality); the wish-fulfilment storyline; and the Lynchian nightmare or exaggerated grotesque. The difficulty comes with picking which scenes fall into which category especially as the Lynch fantasy elements overlay both the narrative story lines. Even with this in mind things only begin to coalesce in the final 20 minutes and are only fully apparent in the hours after viewing or on subsequent viewings.

Spoiler guide (read in conjunction with non-spoiler guide)

The reality perspective includes the break-up of the lesbian affair; the executive powerplays; the black book/contract killer scenes; prostitution-just-below-the-surface; and the faltering career, disintegration, humiliation and suicide of Diane. The wish-fulfilment angle is primarily the heavenly (in both senses) fantasy of Diane and deals with her Hollywood arrival as 'Betty'; Coco as caretaker; a generous Aunt and her flat; the crash/amnesia of 'Rita' (which allows Diane to be wholly in control of her relationship with Camilla which in reality has ended); and the blue box and triangular key whose contents could be said to be the secret of Hollywood.

Even Diane's fantasy will not permit Betty to be present when Rita discovers that the box is empty. In the Lynch nightmare, introduced via the psycho and his tramp vision, the box contains the escaping miniature star-struck couple whose pedestalisation of Betty cannot be attained, and so they become Diane's final demons.

The two narrative story lines converge (1) in the Silencio Club where the Betty/Rita relationship ends and the dream begins to unravel (2) the meeting of eyes between Betty and director Adam when she misses out on her 'big break' and (3) the discovery of the dead Diane by Camilla & Betty.

title: A weird and thrilling movie - you will either hate it or love it.
review:
This was a very weird and confusing movie..but great..And when thinking about the whole way in which David Lynch outlines what is, in fact, a simple story by connecting a dream with reality...and combining this with a great performance from the actors, an old Hollywood style and a thriller mood - it is a brilliant movie.

David Lynch has really thought it through - and if anyone wants to know just how skilled and carefully played out this movie is then read the review of this website:

http://dir.salon.com/ent/movies/feature/2001/10/23/mulholland_drive_analysis/index.html

The review has the title 'Everything you were afraid to ask about "Mulholland Drive" ' by Bill Wyman, Max Garrone and Andy Klein. And it answers whatever questions one might and also gives a summery of the movie. So don't read it if you haven't seen the film yet. Here is an passage from the review:

***********SPOILER-WARNING***********

'What the fuck is going on in this movie?

Well, it seems that Diane had her girlfriend murdered. Then, in a masturbatory fantasy cum fever dream in the moments before she commits suicide, she reimagines her ruined career and failed relationship

with the woman she loves.'

The review says it all...more than I ever could...to all you (confused) people out there.

title: Los Angeles is where all of our dreams lie; Mulholland Dr. is where the dream ends
review:
In `Mulholland Drive,' director David Lynch weaves a story that ingeniously takes our minds on a fantastical roller coaster ride.

The movie opens with the arrival of an ingenue, an aspiring actress named Betty Elms (Naomi Watts), to Hollywood in pursuit of her dreams of becoming a movie star, or a great actress, as she tells us. To Betty, Los Angeles seems the city of Dreams, the city of Angels, a temple where the yearning to dream the impossible is consecrated, a sanctuary for all those who dare to dream. However, immersed in the fantastical sceneries, the somewhat obscure plotline, and the eerie, nerve-striking music, everything in `Mulholland Drive' wears a mysterious and ghastly veil as if foreshadowing the ultimate defeat of these effervescent yearnings.

As Betty soon involves herself in helping the vulnerable Rita (Laura Elena Harring), whom Betty finds in her apartment, to overcome Rita's amnesia, one senses the looming danger ahead. Then, the movie indeed takes a turn, but it arrives at a most unexpected place. It becomes haunting, ludicrous, and dream-like, enthralling us with its confusions, delirium, eeriness, and eroticism. Suddenly, what seemed once a passionate love becomes uncontrollable selfish desires, as mystery turns into an enigma and then transforms itself into a labyrinth. The audience begins to doubt the validity and authenticity of all of which we have seen. Seeking truth, we question what is reality, and what is made-believe illusion.

The performances given by the lead actresses, Watts and Harring, greatly augment the effectiveness of this intriguing tale of aspiration and defeat. Watts is a revelation in her dual role as Betty and Diane, offering a soul to each of the two counterparts, rendering a riveting breakthrough performance of her career. Unfortunately, her Oscar-caliber performance was overlooked by the Academy, but it'll be the performance that'll define her career in the years to come.

9/10

title: Lynch's Finest
review:
The first time I saw Mulholland Drive I was overwhelmed and driven almost insane with frustration.

The second time I saw Mulholland Drive I was familiar with the imagery and suspenseful parts and was more free to examine the plot and try to unravel the mystery.

Somewhere between the second and third viewing I though "I got it." The third watching proved I was right, I think.

Most movies don't require a person to invest so much energy in them and it's understandable that many people will not like this film. But for puzzle lovers, David Lynch must be some kind of god. It is a credit to him as a director that no one has ever dared attempt to make a Lynchian film. Unlike the endless Tarantino knock offs who merely possess geek-like knowledge of trashy cinema, no one can duplicate the clearly weird and wonderful imaginings of David Lynch's head.

Naomi Watts is incredible in this. It wasn't until the end when I realized that Betty was Diane's dream version of herself that I appreciated how wonderful this performance really was.

The most important scene in the film is the one that takes place in the club Silencio. It is a metaphor for the whole film and if you can work that out then the rest of the film will unfold more easily.

Brilliantly fascinating and frustrating Mullholland Drive is a mystery wrapped in a riddle set in a place of sunshine and bright lights but it's message is as dark as they come.

Now if someone could help me Lost Highway....

title: A real masterpiece from a real master
review:
Some directors are good, some are bad, some are brilliant and some are real Gods. David Lynch is in this last category, his visual art is elegant and amazing, and his films are real masterpieces.

The first movie that I watched from this great movie master was Wild at Heart!!!! I was astonished, I felt like if I was in a gallery surrounded by beautiful paintings and wonderful pictures, I was in shock.

From that moment I felt the urgency, the big thirst of looking for all the past movies of Lynch. So that, I could have a big picture of his work.

I found everything about Lynch, from ERASERHEAD to TWIN PEAKS; I became a collector of his work. Every year, since he made FIRE WALK WITH ME, I was exciting waiting for his new work.

And then he made Lost Highway, The Straight Story and Mulholland Drive.

All different movies, but with something in common, his director, his personal view and touch

David Lynch is a surrealist artist. Like Luis Buñuel, Lynch is one director who knows how to manage the strange, the noir, the dreams and the nightmares in his films. And he does it excellent, flawless!!!!

MULHOLLAND DR. is a brilliant movie, is the Lynch world at his best form.

The club El Silencio is a key place to understand the film. To love this masterpiece you don't have to be a Lynch's fan. You'll like it if you love good movies.

Laura Harring and Naomi Watts, both of them play two different characters, and that's why this movie is a puzzle.

Naomi Watts as Betty/Diane play a powerful character, her acting is thrilling. And this movie, at the start is her nightmare, and at the end is her true destiny.

Of course you'll find some strange characters, something usual in Lynch's movies. The Cowboy, Mr. Roque, The man behind Winkies and the Castigliane brothers. They are all created by Diane in her own dreams.

The performance of `Crying' by Rebekah del Rio, is devastating. This is a beautiful song written by the great Roy Orbison. She sings it without instruments, without orchestra.

Don't look for sense in this movie, like Lost Highway, this is a dream/nightmare that may mess up your sense of the right way movies goes on. Just watch it and enjoy it, which is the best you can do. Remember the real world of Diane is the last twenty five minutes of the movie, all the rest is her dream.

In this movie Lynch works with his regular collaborators: Angelo Badalamenti, (since Blue Velvet he started a rich relationship with the director) with a great original music; Peter Deming an excellent cinematography and Mary Sweeney with a flawless film editing.

This great film won several awards, Lynch won the Best Director award at the Cannes Film festival in the year 2001. Also he received an Academy Award Nomination.

Mulholland Drive is a fine masterpiece in visual art. This is real interaction between the movie and the audience, you can feel like if you are in a gallery, watching pictures.

David Lynch is with no doubt, one of the best directors in cinema history

This film deserves 10/10.

title: My all-time favorite film.
review: One of my favorite things about this film is the freedom I have to theorize what I want about certain items and events in the film and all the symbolism that I see.  I know that David Lynch likes to keep his own theories on his films pretty secret and that is great.  By doing this every one who views the film sees something completely different and no one will prove their theories wrong.  Beyond that I think that the film is one of the most beautiful that I have ever seen.  I think the acting is superb and the story is my favorite ever written.  This is one of the few dramas that I can watch more than once a year.  I love all of the elements of it and I seem to spot something new or come up with a new theory every time that I view it.

title: pure genius
review: This is David's best work to date and stands to be a Lynch classic.  My favorite scene is the opening sequences that lead up to the eerie limo driving down the dark road.  There is a funeral tone set by Angelo Badalementi's excellent music scores that are very captivating through out Lynch's masterpiece.  I wish David lynch would allow commentary on his DVD's, even the actors perspective would be of interest.  This film could be watched several times and inspire different revelations as to what is really going on.  Naomi Watts and Laura Herring gave amazing performances, as did the cowboy.  Does anyone have a good theories for the significance to Winkies and the guy having nightmares about the "thing" behind the dumpster? Mulholland Dr. is like a never ending puzzle that I cant stop analyzing!

title: Two hours of nonsense.
review:
Let's get something straight here. This movie is awful. David Lynch has made three brilliant films in his career: 1) Eraserhead, 2) Blue Velvet, 3) Wild at Heart. The rest of his films are nonsensical, ego-stroking trash.

I'm not gonna lie - this film kept my interest throughout. But the only reason for that was the sexy relationship between Naomi Watts and Laura Harring.

I'm just after reading a number of the reviews on this film, and I'm utterly amazed that people react to it the way they do. Newsflash, folks: Just because David Lynch is quirky and tries to be "groundbreaking" and "original", that doesn't mean there's any artistic merit attached to his work. If David Lynch filmed himself on the toilet for two hours, I'm sure most of you people would call it art and claim that it's brilliant. Give me a freaking break.

title: drivel
review: Now this movie is what I label as a classic.. classic example of wasted time. This is one of those films that people like to read way too much into to find a deeper, darker meaning, when it is actually what it is on the surface. Nothing. Well, two things- the same things the movies have been spewing forth since the silents- Hollywood is corrupted and life plays tricks on you. Big deal. I can't blame ABC for not wanting this on their TV line up (it was originally planned as a TV series). In my opinion, David Lynch added some minor porn sequences, which guaranteed it as a hit. The only shining moment in the whole thing was Ann Miller yelling, "If that damn dog c***s in this courtyard one more time..." Sure, this film makes you want to analyze it, but there's nothing more than what I said before. It's perfectly suited for those pseudo-intellectuals who like to think that they can unlock the mysteries of life in a 2 hour long film. My advice- go rent another Ann Miller movie, Kiss Me Kate, and see what real talent, direction, and cinematography is.

title: A terrifying, exciting ride
review:
With this being my first David Lynch film, I'm pretty certain that I've BARELY even begun to scratch the surface in terms of how far his other films can go in terms of surreal, haunting atmosphere. I had heard a lot about this controversial director, of course, and was looking forward to watching this very much after reading about it...and by the time it reached the end credits, I can safely say this was without a doubt the most @#$%ed-up (I mean that in the most affectionate way possible) film I have ever feasted my eyes upon!

In addition to having a well-crafted and mind-numbingly complex storyline (which I actually managed to follow with some degree of success), "Mulholland Dr." is also full of some of the most incredible cinematography and direction I've ever seen. Furthermore, I couldn't be more impressed by the stellar performances from all cast members, especially Naomi Watts and Laura Elena Harring as the two deeply mysterious leads. This is certainly a unique, disturbing piece of work that is sure to remain burned into my psyche for a long, long time. I can't fully express my zombie-like state of horror by film's end, when the slew of images that occurred in those last several minutes haunted me silly. I was very much afraid to do anything at that time. I suppose that's when you know you've made some powerfully effective material.

Kudos to Mr. Lynch...you're a fascinating director whom I will be watching for some time now.

title: Self recognition - through a glass darkly
review: I saw this movie last night for the first time. I have never seen any David Lynch.... and I have never seen or read any interpretations of his work by professional or amateur critics / spoilers etc My reaction seems to be slightly different from many others, who find the crucial shift of perspective baffling and/or irritating  ... for me the movie was redeemed by that sudden change (Diane wakes up ) ... 2/3rds of the way through the movie and on to the end. Although up untill then I had very much enjoyed a lot of things about it, I was becoming restless ... I thought the exposition was over-extended ...  the devices were already much used, and just beginning to pall. The first 2/3rds of the movie could benefit from many cuts ... tightening up etc. However..  in retrospect, as a whole, the overall idea/formal structure is terribly well realised. There are many sensual, visual pleasures of the film .... but  it's great achievement is the sense of psychological self-recognition evoked eventually ... self recognition - not self-understanding. Even if only for a moment, we admit it to ourselves  - that our own grasp of reality is not what we think... and that we kid ourselves that we have some control ! The the last 1/3rd of the movie comes like a sudden slap in the face ... and that shock echoes on. The final few seconds are grim...  but one of the best things I've seen on film.

title: Accept the challenge, people
review:
I've decided that David Lynch films are a dividing line between two types of moviegoers, say, the "sheer entertainers" and the "thought provokers." I'd like to count myself in the latter, and Mulholland Dr. is one of the best in that department for its rich metaphors and its extraordinary mind game. If you are in the former group, you should at least like the imagery in Mulholland Dr., but don't go writing its unconventional storyline off to "drugs" or calling the film a "waste of time" before admitting you just aren't up to Lynch's challenge. Mulholland Dr. is a stellar film.

(As per the chapterless DVD--you have to think Lynch did it on purpose, and frankly, i like that game as well...)

title: you people don't know nothing, do you?
review:
*spoiler spoiler spolier alert!!!!*

alright, for all you people who want to insist that this film makes no sense or that lynch is just screwing with his audience i offer this explanation of mulholland dr.:

and, before i go into it, you should be aware of three preoccupations of mr. lynch's: psychoanalysis (which is the foundation for surrealism, by the way), hollywood cinema of the studio era (specifically the work of hitchcock), and the avant garde. these crop up again and again in his movies, blue velvet even uses shadow of a doubt as a foundation

okay, in the opening sequence of the film we see a) a bunch of people dancing and b) a pillow accompanied by heavy breathing. at the end of the film, diane (naomi watts) will say that she got to hollywood by winning a jitterbug contest and then she will commit suicide on her bed. so, basically, doing the jitterbug led to this girl's suicide which is why those two images are juxtaposed prominently in the beginning of the film

the last third of the movie (the portion after they visit club silencio) is the "real" world, of course there is no "real" it's a movie people. but yeah the scenes of a struggling actress named diane who was the lover of another more successful actress named camilla and was then dumped by camilla for the director of the film they were both working on is what constitutes "reality" in the movie. diane was dumped and humiliated by camilla and so she hired a hitman to take care of camilla and received a blue key after the hit was done then she was haunted by freaky old people who represented her overwhelming guilt and was driven to suicide.

now, the rest of the movie is diane's brain in its death throes reorganizing the stuff it experienced in the past couple days and trying to come to terms with having been penetrated by a bullet. the suicide becomes the car crash on mulholland dr. and diane's personality is split into two polar opposites, rita and betty. the polar opposites investigate the car crash and are led to the discovery of betty's suicide at which point they are reconciled and rita takes on the likeness of betty and they make with the whoopie. all the other stuff that happens to the other people is diane's brain giving new meaning to trivial and significant things it saw, in her fantasy she is a great actress of course this the psychoanalysis part

one of the more interesting things the movie does is present its first half in a distinctly hitchcockian style (lots of motion concealed cuts, and pov to reaction shots) and offer a pretty conventional amnesia two snooping girls plot in an easily digestable manner. then, when they go to club silencio they see a show that explains all they are seeing is a recording just as all that is on screen is a recorded illusion not actually happening. the exposure of the illusory nature of the cinema was a big no no in hollywood films of the past and was thought to be disruptive. this moment of disruption leads to the exposure of the "real" world which is presented in a very formalistic narratively disordered style which is what art is supposed to be. there is a thinly veiled commentary on the nature of the cinema here as what is "real" intratextually is presented in a more formalistic manner than what is strictly fantasy

my point is this: just because you can't figure out how something operates doesn't mean it doesn't have a logical (perhapes not rational) means of operation. all art operates on some terms no matter how unclear or arbitrary they may at first seem to you. and sure there's a lot of stuff i'm not covering here and honestly i don't even understand it all (like the scary bum) but hey mysteries are meant to be solved and as such CAN be solved. build on what i have said

title: You will never forget this beautiful Nightmare
review:
What can I say about this incredible Movie? Like `Lost Highway` Lynch shows us a world full of dark secrets and forbidden mysteries, where the minds of the protagonists were divided or multiplied into other characters by the unseen.

Everyone in this movie has a secret and Dianes existence is for the beginning like a perfect dream which came reality. But that dream gets out of control, and the beautiful life of Diane changes to a surreal nightmare. The part in the theater with Diane and Camilla is a SCREAM. Lynch at his best. He mixes mystery and love with a dark atmosphere never seen it before, and what came out, are great. You fill the pain of Diane and Camilla. In this moment you know that the two Ladies are in great trouble, because they are one person who splitted, and the only consolation is they´re love.

At last I must say that the end of the movie is the most shocking I´ve ever seen. My opinion is that every movie from David Lynch makes you to a better human being. The people who don´t understand this I can´t help and I gave this masterpiece a 10 from 10.

title: One of the most remarkable films in recent years
review: A gripping, yet fragmentary, impressionistic story of a girl-girl-guy love triangle, actually centering on the two lovers, Betty and "Rita" (as in Hayworth's Gilda).  This film is very funny, but I encountered an audience which seemed intent on taking it very "seriously".  It's a satire of Hollywood, and Lynch is a director who makes the creation of a film the motivation of the plot itself.  In order for a Lynch film to exist, there must be a "replacement" leading lady who must be killed (of course).  It is consciously referential to "Gilda", and seems to reference at least 3 other films:  "Carnival of Souls", "The Wizard of Oz", and "Barton Fink."  I love how Betty looks like Doris Day in Lynchland when she steps off the plane. Although the audience laughed at the old people, they soon went back to sitting on their hands and taking the film as high art, when they really should have just been having a good time and a good laugh.  Consquently, there were many puzzled expressions when exiting the theater.

title: lynch makes a collage of his previous work
review:
Don't get me wrong, I am a great admirer of Lynch's work. Not just his beautifully strange haunting films, but his painting and photography as well. I have seen Lost Highway at least five times and it still intrigues me. I think Eraserhead is one of the scariest cult horrors I have seen. The calming beauty of Straight Story couldn't have been captured by anyone else but Lynch. The image of Bob from Twin Peaks can stil make me shiver thinking about it... but... Mulholland Drive didn't do those things for me.

I think it is Lynch's most overrated work so far. When these other films came out people were probably not ready for them yet. When Mulholland Drive came out, I guess they were, so it was hauled by the press and audience as something they had never seen before. And this is exactly where I think the film gets stuck!

I almost feel bad giving this critical review, but I feel by doing this I am actually doing credit to the genius of Lynch's mind. Although I'm not sure if the man himself would agree! I think Lynch could do better. Let me start by saying that I did enjoy the film. The atmosphere was still beautiful dreamy like. It did miss the nightmarish dimension of Lost Highway though. Maybe cuz Betty, even when she turns darker, was so annoyingly nice and sweet. There was a fair amount of your regular dry humor and some of the characters managed to give me the creeps for a moment, be it that they never had a deeper function.

The plot itself soon lost my interest. Maybe cuz I already knew the trick not to look for a binding thread too much. You know with Lost Highway I still look for a missing piece of the puzzle, but in Mulholland Drive there are so many missing pieces you soon give up. Maybe it's not fair that I'm comparing this film to Lost Highway so much, but what can you expect when even the music, pretty decisive in creating the atmosphere, was identical at times.

Then there was the dwarf we know from Twin Peaks. Didn't Lynch have any new ideas of creating some other crazily disturbing characters? As if he put them in for people unfamiliar with his work. Or is Mulholland Drive an ode, a collage, to what he did before. An ode out of the mind of some disturbed girl with a multiple personality syndrome?

We know Lynch has a very typical way of handling the camera, which was one of the reasons to make a film with such a common story as The Straight Story still so beautiful and strange. The camerawork of Mulholland Drive was too identical to Lost Highway though, but not as effective. I didn't get any goosebumps. I just felt dreamily entertained for two and a half hours.

The love scenes between Rita and Betty were nice and seemed sincere. Their relationship as a whole was convincing. That's were I liked the twist in the plot. But then a lot of the rest seemed kind of useless entourage. I don't know but Mulholland Drive really disappointed me coming out of this brilliant mind, I'm sorry to say...

title: ...and David Lynch furrowed his brow...
review:
You know, I'm fairly certain David Lynch didn't exert as many brain cells developing this film as the audience has trying to decipher it. I'm among the guilty who constantly over-analyze this man's work. I love him, love what he does, thank goodness he's around to stir things up. But sometimes a cigar is just a cigar. I have to accept that. Almost every image, every line of dialogue, in "Mulholland Dr." is beautifully, devilishly open to symbolic interpretation. And these interpretations are, unfortunately (or gleefully?), as unique as the audience members forming them, and probably based more on their own life experiences and filtered more through their own perceptions than any David Lynch may have intended. In that regard, "Mulholland Dr." can be equated with a dream.

I enjoyed the parallels drawn between the Hollywood system and the mob. The relationship between Betty/Diane and Rita/Camilla was deep, believable. The score (as expected) was right on target. And then there were those gorgeous colors and sumptuous fabrics and eccentric peripheral characters. Yes, a blue box, that one girl had; a blue key the other girl had. Death in the guise of a dark, disfigured, and hirsute man living out behind the Winkie's Cafe ("Winkie's", get it?). Pillows and bed sheets and only a slight bump in the chronological order of things there towards the end. But follow a few clues, like "okay, she just came to get the ashtray, but in the next scene it's still on the table"... and you'll be just fine.

Not rocket science here. Just art. Mull all, and drive.

title: Provocative and mesmerizing! The best ride at the theme park!
review:
I'm not going to give away the the plot details of the story like so many other reviewers have done here because I honestly feel that doing so will only undermine the artistry and impact of this film. But I have to say that I am completely flabbergasted by how many people did not get this movie! So many of today's movies want to be so blatantly obvious, and force their linear stories down our throats. I'm so tired of watching predictable plots that have neither substance nor appeal. And what makes me even crazier is that most of the studios, and worse yet many directors (and some actors) are convinced that this is what we all want! They think we're all babies that need to be spoon-fed a story in excruciating detail, instead of letting us connect-the-dots on our own! Then along comes this obscure little movie that I hardly knew anything about. I expected it to be pretty much the same as all the rest of those boring movies. Boy was I in for a surprise! All at once I get thrown into this abstract dream sequence that keeps me transfixed from beginning to end. So much so, that I couldn't sleep and I had to watch the movie again to try to fit the pieces together. That same night I had a long weird dream of my own.
